video.title: The 2024 Games I Didn't Review | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Well, let&#39;s set up our little deckchairs in 
the usual blasted No Man&#39;s Land of January,

made all the more bleak by everyone being huddled 
in their bunkers waiting for the Grand Theft Auto

6 launch date to drop and land on everyone&#39;s 
schedules like the fucking Tunguska event,

so let&#39;s indulge our regular routine of tying up 
the loose ends from 2024, such as, &quot;Why didn&#39;t you

do anything with Concord, Yahtzee? Surely triple-A 
publishers getting buggered over an ironing board

is the thing you picture in your mind every 
time you blow out your birthday candles; Sony&#39;s

half-billion live service failure should have 
been red meat to you.&quot; It certainly was, listener,

but all the best chops of the red meat got taken 
before I even got to the carcass. I didn&#39;t even

have a chance to play Concord; it&#39;d come and gone 
from online stores by the time I even heard what

a delightful shitfest it was. Nothing one can do 
now but retroactively take the piss out of the

character designs, and I&#39;d like to think that&#39;s 
beneath me. I really would LIKE to think that.

Oh, look everyone, it&#39;s the adventures of parallel 
universe Doctor Robotnik after they got mauled by

a rabid set square, and her best friend&#39;s bastard 
offspring of Michael Rooker and an artichoke,

photo negative of Alucard from Hellsing, the Quake 
1 protagonist&#39;s embarrassing mum standing too

close to a heat lamp, wet-weather Gabe Newell, 
someone who cobbled together their World of

Warcraft costume in five minutes in the alleyway 
behind the convention center, &#39;80s synth pop music

act representing Anorexia Awareness Month, the 
cafeteria tray that walks like a man, etc., etc.,

etc. Phew, that was fun, actually. Man, I&#39;ve 
never seen this many pastel colors and rounded

sunglasses in one place; it&#39;s like watching 
John Lennon choke to death on candy love hearts.

I&#39;m a little embarrassed about this one. 
I played Animal Well and found it to be a

perfectly functional Metroidvania with some cool 
imagery and interesting twists on traversal; it

brought back fond memories of those old Commodore 
64 explorative platform games where you go screen

to screen, avoiding patrolling, multicolored 
Mickey Mouse heads and spinning refrigerators,

and the protagonist is a nondescript blob that&#39;s 
all the memory limit will allow. But everyone kept

going on about how it had some transcendent shit 
going on with post-ending stuff, and I just wasn&#39;t

seeing that. So I did some research and discovered 
that the interesting stuff was only going to start

after I found one more hidden egg. But I didn&#39;t 
have the first idea where to start looking for it,

I thought I&#39;d already checked everywhere, 
and frankly, I had other shit to do. So it

just got away from me. I apologize, Animal Well. 
It&#39;s not you; it&#39;s me. I got tired of searching

every nook and cranny for leftover eggs when 
I had to go to Whole Foods on Christmas Eve.

A short horror adventure &quot;experience&quot; that I 
was hesitant to fully review because it isn&#39;t

very long and only barely escapes the &quot;walking 
simulator&quot; label thanks to some slightly annoying

arcadey bits and several inventory puzzles 
where you go into one of two available rooms,

pick up a thing, and take it to the only other 
available room, but it&#39;s a very absorbing story

experience. As recommendations go, it&#39;s 
a heavily qualified one. &quot;Hey, check this

game out. It&#39;s really horrible and upsetting; 
you&#39;ll love it.&quot; The premise is a small group

of low-level workers on a spaceship crew under 
the heel of a massive, uncaring corporation are

stranded by a disaster with no certainty of rescue 
and nothing to eat but a cargo of mouthwash. And

through a series of events and hallucination 
sequences presented in nonlinear order,

the situation inevitably decays, and we discover 
that everything was completely fucked from the

start and they might as well have all cut their 
fucking throats from the word &quot;go.&quot; So yeah,

feelgood hit of the summer. But made weirdly 
compelling through some unique, iconic visuals.

It&#39;s so...what&#39;s the word...visceral? It really 
helped me appreciate how context and sound design

can make an act as simple as opening someone&#39;s 
mouth for them into something really bloody gross.

I&#39;ve kept my eye on Supermassive Games and their 
parade of glorified Choose Your Own Adventure

books in much the way an oncologist keeps their 
eye on a worrying growth in somebody&#39;s prostate,

but I do think there&#39;s potential there. Until Dawn 
and Man of Medan were alright. But after playing

through their new one, Casting of Frank Stone, I 
didn&#39;t think it worth reviewing because there&#39;d

been no improvement in any of Supermassive&#39;s 
key problem areas. To wit: their inability to

come up with a single fucking character who 
didn&#39;t richly deserve a brick to the teeth,

none of your choices mattering for two squirts 
of mung on the back of a gravedigger&#39;s shovel

in the first three quarters of the game, and 
the last quarter being an incomprehensible,

horribly edited mess when your choices start 
mattering too much. The only thing worth

noting about Casting of Frank Stone is that 
it&#39;s set in the Dead by Daylight universe,

of all things, and sets out to establish how the 
whole situation of that game came about. And I

figured I already knew how it came about. 
Behaviour Interactive wanting to bank off

a successful live service game for the rest of 
their fucking lives. And a whole bunch of owners

of defunct horror IPs needing to earn a living and 
there only being so many conventions in a year.

With so many indie games fighting for my 
attention a 50,000-strong Overwhelmingly

Positive review rating on Steam is definitely one 
way to stand out, but it soon became clear that

MiSide was benefiting from the influence of the 
weeb demographic. Because if there&#39;s one thing the

weebs love more than weeby dating sims, it&#39;s weeby 
dating sims with deniability. &quot;Oh, no, actually we

like it because it&#39;s secretly a subversive horror 
game in the Doki Doki Literature Club mold with

an interesting metanarrative about being trapped 
in a video game world with a fun smorgasbord of

gameplay mechanics and creative set pieces and 
not because there&#39;s a hot anime babe in it and

we want to imagine being a slug slowly crawling up 
the outside of her exposed thighs.&quot; Uh-huh. MiSide

was somewhat fun, but it really straddles the line 
between &quot;subversive pretend pervy weeby game&quot; and

&quot;actual pervy weeby game.&quot; Even being chainsaw 
murdered by the hot anime babe had a distinctly

fetish-y vibe. The total giveaway was when I beat 
the game and unlocked &quot;nonsubversive actual dating

sim mode.&quot; Although when I started it with wanking 
hand poised, it just said, &quot;Oh, sorry, we haven&#39;t

finished this yet; come back in six months.&quot; 
Weak, guys. Say you&#39;re early access if you&#39;re

still in early access. Don&#39;t be such a fucking 
tease. Oh. Guess that&#39;s on brand, actually.

But let&#39;s end things and go into 2025 on a much 
fucking needed positive note. I played Sorry

We&#39;re Closed over the holidays after it was 
recommended. &quot;Hey Yahtz, have you played this

game? It&#39;s really fucking weird, like you.&quot; So 
I did, and now I pay forward the recommendation

to my fellow weirdos. It&#39;s like—bear with me on 
this—it&#39;s like if Resident Evil had a horrible,

misshapen PS1-graphics baby with Catherine 
and the midwife was SUDA51, and if every

single character was gay. You play a hipster, 
lovelorn, cyan-haired convenience store clerk

who gets seduced by a demon—I say &quot;seduced&quot;; it&#39;s 
more like, &quot;Fall in love with me or I&#39;ll pull your

legs off and ram them up your pisshole&quot;—and 
has to explore a series of dungeons to avoid

becoming the new plaything of Hell. It combines 
Persona-esque division of time between surface

reality and dungeon descents with an engaging 
story that&#39;s at heart about relationships and

how no one really understands how love works, 
especially not leg-pulling nightmare demons.

It&#39;s also got an innovative combat system based 
around rapidly shooting sequences of weak spots

that I found rather refreshing, if only because 
it didn&#39;t employ a dodge button or a timed parry

like every other fucking combat system lately. 
Yes, alright, games industry, we get it. Timed

parries are fun. I think Magic Shell&#39;s fun; I 
wouldn&#39;t use it to paint my fucking living room.
